then we're going to hear from the team at the University of Maryland for and get into some of the details on how
they're using tableau in production so to start things off considering why
you're using VI on the cloud you have lots of different data sources lots of
different places things are places data is coming from lots of different use cases a few trends we're seeing first is
moving data into s3 as an initial landing spot from there we frequently
see customers using EMR our Hadoop distribution to ETL data as well as to
query it leveraging a data warehouse and then finally using tableau to gain
insight and value from that data wrong
button so tableau has a number of advantages one of them is the awesome
number of integrations that has especially with AWS data sources so we
see customers using redshift our cloud native data warehouse solution that can
handle data from gigabyte scale up to petabytes with fast cost-effective performance you see customer is using
EMR our hadoop distribution and leveraging tools like spark or hive
on top of that we also see customers leveraging Amazon Athena it's a fairly
new service of ours that lets you run sequel queries against data in s3 without having to you manage or
provision servers you just write a query you get a result so a few practical
considerations when you're running tableau on AWS there are a number of
ways to deploy it the first is a self-service model where you provision
an ec2 instance you install the software onto it you provision your license and you're
off and running another approach is leveraging the AWS marketplace the
marketplace is a storefront where you can purchase software from a wide range
of our partners the marketplace will
provide you with a pre-configured machine image so you just have to launch
the instance with that image and you're set to start using the tool in the case
of tableau we have two options through the marketplace the first is a BYO l option bring your own license so here
you leverage the pre-installed pre-configured machine image and you use
an existing license you have with tableau server so you can get up and
running quickly and leverage the investment you've already made the second option is to leverage a license
that you acquire through the marketplace here you can start small and scale up as
you go so you have the pay-as-you-go pricing model similar to other AWS
services so when you think about tableau one of the aspects the University of
Maryland found really useful is the ability to start small and grow as your
demand grows so you're only paying for the resources you're using as you're using but we really encourage customers
to provision a small ec2 instance when you're getting going
and as your business need grows you can move to a larger and larger instance there two approaches to scaling tableau
on AWS the first is a vertical approach here you're going to start with a
smaller ec2 instance and provision larger instances if you need them so you
might start with m5 large and as your users are running more reports as you
have more users you can move to an m5 extra large or an m5 to extra large to
meet that need the second approach is scaling horizontally here you're
leveraging tableau servers ability to run up primary and multiple worker nodes
and you can just add additional worker nodes as your demand grows so few
architectural considerations when you're using tableau on AWS you're going to
start with ec2 instance that has the software installed then you're going to
look at your data sources so this could be redshift this could be a relational
database you're using on RDS or this could be a system like EMR you're going
to want to make sure that those resources are secure typically customers are going to want to
have access to databases really locked down you don't want malicious activity or
accidental exposure of data so you can use security groups which are stateful firewalls that AWS provides to restrict
access to your databases so that only tableau it server is able to access
those data sources thinking about defense and depth you can also leverage
VP C's and subnets within those VP C's to control where traffic is coming from
so you have a public subnet to your tableau server sitting in
traffic from outside the V PC can reach in and then you can put your databases in private sub nuts so that only traffic
from within the V PC is able to reach those final consideration is where your
users are coming from when they're accessing tableau server one approach is to leverage a public internet so you can
have traffic flowing over the public Internet and hitting tableau server another approach we see especially with our
larger customers is to leverage private network connectivity so you can either set up a direct connect or VPN to extend
your on-premise network into AWS and let customers connect over that so I'm going
to turn it over to madeleine from tableau now all right thanks Ryan

here because we see that customers are all across the board here especially with people using tableau we have
customers who are fully deployed on the cloud they've been there for years and they're actually leading the way in

however a consistent theme there is that enterprise IT is playing a strong cloud governance role now that means that IT

Lake where you can collect all of your information now it comes into that into
that s3 bucket that you designate in a compressed zipped file and you get a

often sometimes get a little bit of duplication just because fact of the matter is you're getting a lot of data shoved in there so the next thing I
needed was a way to clean that up and this is an important point because I wanted to clean it up so that I could open it in tableau and for those of you

and one of the downsides to procuring AWS through a reseller is you don't have access to the payer account so I can't
use the AWS and native tools for doing spend analysis I don't have access to budgets I don't have access to cost
Explorer they recently announced support for reserved instance coverage information and I have access to any of
that it's all in the master account and my reseller owns that we don't know that so the solution we came up with was to

of dimensions that are available in that data and so one of the first reports we
developed and probably one of the most important ones is the ability to do analysis of our reserved instance
coverage we have over 70 active AWS accounts and there's no having access to
the master account there's no native tools for analyzing your reserved instance covered across all of those accounts at once so this report shows
two things at the bottom you'll see instance counts by our and by instance
type so in blue it's t2 micro T to small T to medium that kind of thing and the spikes you're seeing there are most of
our applications most of our users of our applications are on the East Coast most of them work business hours and so you're seeing scale out spikes Monday to
Friday 8:00 to 6:00 as usual using the applications and as developers are spinning up development and QA
environments for doing work in testing but you see if the top is normalized
usage of those reserved instances so AWS has a reserved instance feature called
instance type flexibility this on linux instances means that you can buy a t2
micro reserved instance and apply it to half of a t2 small or you buy a tea to
small reserved instance and apply it to to teaching micro so you don't have to worry about as much the different sizes of instances that you're using you can
just buy tea to reserve capacity have it apply across the board they take care of all that for you automatically and so
the top part of that graph is showing you those normalized units and what we do as a team is sit down once a month and kind of analyze how much we're using
how much of that is reserved how much of that is on-demand what do we think we're gonna be doing next month the month after that we can see a kind of a slow
steady trend up on this graph and we buy our eyes once a month to kind of keep between 80 and 90 percent of our
on-demand coverage this next report makes use of a tagging structure we
apply to all of our resources in AWS and has a number of dimensions that let us drill down into individual applications
that we run we have a Java platform as a service we provide to our developers to run most of our enterprise applications
and this lets us get cost for each individual application the environments that applications run so dev versus QA
versus production and it actually has a drill down on the right-hand side to allow you to see the underlying AWS
services and components that make up that cost so one of the top ones on there is testudo that's our student
information system I can drill down into the production cost versus the development I can see how much we're
spending on ec2 compute vs. storage versus data transfer how much we're spending on cloud watch metrics how much
you're spending on load balancers all that kind of stuff one of the things that came out of being able to do this
analysis was the realization that we were spending quite a bit of money on load balancers and they were mostly idle
those balancers as I mentioned earlier our non production environments are off most of the time unless the developers
using them there's no off button on a load balancer I can stop an ec2 instance I can turn an auto scaling group down to
zero you're paying for load balance whether you're sending traffic through it or not as long as it exists and so that led us
to with a couple of AWS features a model we called shared lb where AWS in their
application load balancer product came out a couple of features where you can have that load balancer route traffic to
different target groups based on HTTP host headers and they raised the limit on the number of routing rules from ten
to a hundred what that let us do was take a single load balancer and configure it to route traffic to
multiple independent applications underneath based on whatever the URL the user typed in so rather than one load balancer for application I can have one
per essentially 100 applications so this is a report that we didn't publish we
didn't make available to campus it's still using the same template that Tom created so at least it looks reasonable
from a look and feel point of view but made available to the team that was rolling out that shared load balancer
model so they can track the progress what you'll see is we went from in our Drupal environment spending a three thousand dollars a month on load
balancers to when this is all said and done we're spending about four hundred dollars on load balancers this graph flips back and forth between cost and
load balancer count and the load balancer count side which is popping up in a second you'll see some pretty
